`script/build --code-sign --install`

NOTE: After upgrading git to 2.10.1 from 2.10

data.title: On MacOS X "Home" and "End" keys do not work as expected
data.body:
### Description

On MacOS 10.11.6 Atom 1.10.2 (even in safe mode) the "home" and "end" keys on my extended keyboard don't do the right thing. "home" moves to the start of the line and "end" moves to the end of line.

The key resolver shows that this is caused by:

```
"atom-text-editor": {
    "home": "editor:move-to-first-character-of-line",
    "end": "editor:move-to-end-of-screen-line",
    "shift-home": "editor:select-to-first-character-of-line",
    "shift-end": "editor:select-to-end-of-line"
  },
```

in `/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/keymaps/base.json`

Bindings for what appear to be more traditional behavior, e.g. `core:move-to-top` for `home`, are also present in /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/node_modules/tree-view/keymaps/e-view.json` but are being overridden by the above.

I realize I can work around this, but it seems to me that the default ought to be fixed.

data.title: Differing results in specs and Atom itself
data.body:
Hello

I'm encountering a strange problem whilst running package specs in Atom: the scope descriptors I get from the specs don't seem to be the same as those in the actual editor. I may very well be doing something wrong here, so feel free to stop me if I am.

I have the following simple PHP code:

``` php
<?php

$test = \Test\CONST_TEST;
```

Putting this into an editor, the `\Test\` part of the scope descriptor has `.support.other.namespace.php` in its scope chain according to the developer tools. I can verify this via my package:

``` coffeescript
editor.scopeDescriptorForBufferPosition([2, 10]).getScopeChain()
```

This yields `.text.html.php .meta.embedded.block.php .source.php .support.other.namespace.php`, which is correct. However, if I put this into my spec:

``` coffeescript
describe "Test", ->
    editor = null
    grammar = null

    beforeEach ->
        waitsForPromise ->
            atom.workspace.open().then (result) ->
                editor = result

        waitsForPromise ->
            atom.packages.activatePackage('language-php')

        runs ->
            grammar = atom.grammars.selectGrammar('.text.html.php')

        waitsFor ->
            grammar and editor

        runs ->
            editor.setGrammar(grammar)

    it "gives different results from an actual Atom window?", ->
        source =
            """
            <?php

            $test = \Test\CONST_TEST;
            """

        editor.setText(source)

        lines = editor.getLineCount()

        for line in [0 .. lines - 1]
            text = editor.lineTextForBufferRow(line)

            continue if text.length == 0

            for i in [0 .. text.length - 1]
                chain = editor.scopeDescriptorForBufferPosition([line, i]).getScopeChain()

                console.log([line, i], chain)
```

The entire range `\Test\CONST_TEST` is marked as being a `.text.html.php .meta.embedded.block.php .source.php .constant.other.php`, which is something slightly different from what the editor says. What's strange is that it seems that actual syntax highlighting has occurred, as scope descriptors are present, but only _some_ of them are different from the actual results. Am I perhaps somehow using the wrong grammar?

My apologies if this is in the wrong place, the issue is somewhat tied to the `language-php` package, but since it involves difference in behavior between specs and the actual editors, I thought it might belong here instead.

I'm using Atom version 1.10.2.

Thanks in advance

data.title: Add specs to demonstrate problem with Cursor.getCurrentWordBufferRange
Copy paste file/folder from Atom does not work with Windows Explorer
data.body:
### Description

When copying a file/folder from Atom editor, it does not recognise the paste operation in Windows Explorer. Please see screenshots.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Copy a file/folder in Atom.
2. Go to Windows explorer.
3. Try to paste the file/folder from Atom and it remains greyed out.

**Expected behavior:** 

It would be nice to be able to paste from Atom into Windows Explorer.

**Actual behavior:**

The Paste option is greyed out / disabled in Windows Explorer.
### Versions

Atom 1.10.2

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17824719/19069752/246f7514-8a20-11e6-910b-18ac6c9c8897.png)

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17824719/19069761/32ce3f82-8a20-11e6-9a79-97894f9a7bfc.png)

data.title: --wait does not interact reasonably with the no-prompt-on-close behavior
data.body:
The `--wait` option is intended to allow the use of atom as a step in a command line process such as `git commit` in which the command line process does not proceed until the user closes the file.

This interacts poorly with atom's no-prompt-on-close behavior. When working with `--wait` the file is usually a temporary file, so there is no opportunity to restore the work later.

The `--wait` option should introduce prompt-for-save-on-close behavior. Otherwise the user must take a minimum of two steps in a certain order to avoid "stubbing their toe."

data.title: Code Hint Overlay Jumps Around
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

The position of the code-hint overlay moves around depending on the current selection.  If the cursor is in the right place, the code-hint overlay gives the appearance of jumping as the user moves through the list of code-hint suggestions with arrow keys.  When the overlay moves with each up/down arrow key it's more than annoying.

The overlay probably needs to determine its position based on the items in the list, instead of basing its position on the currently selected item in the suggestion list.

[Description of the bug or feature]
### Steps to Reproduce

ubuntu 16.04
1. position cursor in a file as in screenshot
2. start typing a new line of css and press ctrl-space for code hints
3. use up/down arrow keys to scroll through list of code suggestions.  Watch overlay jump around.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]
Overlay appears, then stays in the same place as the user scrolls through the list with up/down arrow keys.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]
Overlay appears, then moves around the screen as the user scrolls through the list with up/down arrow keys.

![screenshot from 2016-10-03 10-38-10](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/260223/19045698/77bf139c-8957-11e6-866e-a3576caf5661.png)
![screenshot from 2016-10-03 10-40-01](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/260223/19045702/7b19b290-8957-11e6-8d11-63effc353eb1.png)
### Versions

ubuntu 16.04

Atom    : 1.9.9
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0

apm  1.10.0
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.12
git 2.7.4

data.title: As deprecate shadow dom
Support bidi using html5 dir=auto
data.body:
Currently, atoms performs bidirectionality inside each line, but still every line is left aligned. HTML5 has the dir="auto" attribute, that instructs the browser to decide on the direction of the element automatically according to the first character in the line that has directionality associated with it.

If there was a way to add dir="auto" attribute to each line's div, it would improve Atom's bidi handling and allow much more convenient editing of RTL languages such as Hebrew, Arabic and Persian.

data.title: Replace CoffeeScript with IcedCoffeeScript ?
data.body:
[IcedCoffeeScript](http://maxtaco.github.io/coffee-script/) could make developing atom app easier.
It adds the keywords `await` and `defer`:

An example with `CoffeeScript`:

``` coffee
serialSearch = (keywords, cb) ->
  result = []
  i = 0
  launch = () ->
    if i < keywords.length
       j = i++
       search keywords[j], cb_generator j
     else
       cb results
  cb_generator = (i) ->
    (json) ->
      results[i] = json
      launch()
  launch()
```

With `IcedCoffeeScript`:

``` coffee
serialSearch = (keywords, cb) ->
  out = []
  for k,i in keywords
    await search k, defer out[i]
  cb out
```

So simple ;)
